THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 24, 1931

JAYS TO OPEN SEASON
WITH OLYMPIC CLUB
Ferrarini, Brownley, Nickel
and Packard, on Olympic Team
TO HAVE TWO CAPTAINS
Several Freshmen Will Break
Into Hopkins Lineup
For the third consecutive year
the Jay stickmen will open their lacrosse season with a tilt with the
Olympic Club team.
• Next Saturday the Jays meet a
team composed almost wholly of
ex-Hopkins aces, whose work in
the 1928 Olympics led them to the
title of "World's Champions" and
to their subsequent organization as
a club. The "Olympics" have held
regular practices at Homewood,
three times a week for several
weeks and are rounding out a wellbalanced team. Aside from the
wealth of veteran material on hand,
the club boasts the addition of a
number of younger players, late
from college ranks.
Manager Rob Roy of the Olympic organization, has recently added
to his schedule an engagement with
the University of Pennsylvania
team. The inclusion of the "Olympics" in the schedules of such
teams as Hopkins and Pennsylvania is indicative of the respect
borne this group.
Among those men, new to the
ranks of the "Olympics", are Corner Brownley and "Jo" Ferrarini
who played stellar games at goal
for Hopkins in the 1929 and 1930
campaigns.
The Olympic team will have two
captains, this year; the new plan
will see Gardiner Mallonee directing the work of the defense while
Norman Robinson will lead the attack.
The Jays are anxious to continue
their series of victories over the
Olympic Club, having been victorious by the scores of 4-2, and 4-0 in
1929 and 1930. For a number of
the prospective players the coming
engagement will be their first varsity experience.

Levy Named President
Of The Musical Club
Elliott, Kolb And Other Old Members Of The Club
Are Present.
(Continued from page 1, col. 6)

merited on past activities of the organizations. Martin Elliot, pres.,
'30, and Donald Vannernan, manager, '23, joined in supply reminiscences of their membership.
Certificates Awarded

Following the addresses, Peake
presented certificates of membership to those who had been faithful
in service, including about 50 men.
Richard Van Atta was awarded the
first varsity seal of the new type

for 3 years' outstanding service. It
was announced that possibly 4 or 5
more men would receive seals in
June.
John L. Sullivan, '32, was announced to have been elected to
succeed Bert Clarke as leader of
the Blue Jay Orchestra. Wilson
Shugerman and Milton Smith, both
of '33, were elected by ballot to
succeed Levy and Sharretts as
junior managers. The competency
of the latter was cited as recommendation for their being elected.
Evening Is Success

The banquet which was held at
the Southern Hotel was attended
by over 60 persons of affiliation
with the club, Harry Kriel, Robert
George, and Donald Sharretts, former members, attending as guests.
The evening was featured by a
great deal of hilarity.
Peake called for the University
Ode by the Glee Club to open the
evening and it was closed by the
singing of the medley, "Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins," and "Frankie
and Johnnie."

to the fullest extent. Compromise
will lessen its strength. A new power ought be awarded the body. The
Student Council must serve as the
mediating body between students
conflicting with the faculty in any
manner, and students desiring the
repeal of an out-of-date disturbance. With such an additional power, ours will be a more beloved
Student Council.
This is a difficult article to write;
the faults of the campus are difficult
to understand. The undergraduate
must learn his place in the University scale, it must build the future
college from itself, it ought to cooperate more completely with its
best friend—its Dean.
Twenty years from now, the authors will be forgotten, this disorder unrecognizable, and the College of Arts and Sciences a recognized body. Out-of-town-students
will not enter under the delusion
that the college insures admission
to the Medical School—but because
of its educational fame. Radicalists will be properly- squelched. The
faculty will be a harmless, harmonious group of old-timers. Sports
and periodicals may or may not
vanish, but Homewood will be
Homewood—the undergrads will
still date Lutherville women rather
than those or Goucher—the Dorm
will still have its waterfights—the
food will still be condemned as horrible—courses will still be getting
tougher—and other classes will be
preparing for graduation. In the
meantime you and I will be striving to earn bread and butter.

3

Two Were Wounded

The wounding of the undergraduates—J. C. Bryson and
Robert G. Shirley among them—
occurred after a group of undergraduates had hurled snowballs
into windows of the Alumnia Memorial Hall, breaking a number of
panes. After a second missile had
entered the room of the graduate
student, he grasped a heavy air revolver and fired shot after shot at
the fleeing students.
Many of the slugs passed through
the clothing of the snowballthrowers.

Disturbed by the lassitude displayed by members of his 8.30
A. M. classes, Dr. Broadus Mitchell,
associate professor of Political
Economy, attributed this apathy to
sparsity of breakfasts eaten, after
an investigation last Friday morning. He amassed an imposing list
of statistics as to the repasts eaten
by yawning undergrads.
Dr. Mitchell's findings are regarded by many as being revolutionary,
in that they present a phase of the
college man's life that hitherto has
been disregarded, and which may
be the primary reason for the anipathy of all college students against

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 24, 1931

JAYS TO OPEN SEASON
WITH OLYMPIC CLUB
Ferrarini, Brownley, Nickel
and Packard, on Olympic Team
TO HAVE TWO CAPTAINS
Several Freshmen Will Break
Into Hopkins Lineup
For the third consecutive year
the Jay stickmen will open their lacrosse season with a tilt with the
Olympic Club team.
• Next Saturday the Jays meet a
team composed almost wholly of
ex-Hopkins aces, whose work in
the 1928 Olympics led them to the
title of "World's Champions" and
to their subsequent organization as
a club. The "Olympics" have held
regular practices at Homewood,
three times a week for several
weeks and are rounding out a wellbalanced team. Aside from the
wealth of veteran material on hand,
the club boasts the addition of a
number of younger players, late
from college ranks.
Manager Rob Roy of the Olympic organization, has recently added
to his schedule an engagement with
the University of Pennsylvania
team. The inclusion of the "Olympics" in the schedules of such
teams as Hopkins and Pennsylvania is indicative of the respect
borne this group.
Among those men, new to the
ranks of the "Olympics", are Corner Brownley and "Jo" Ferrarini
who played stellar games at goal
for Hopkins in the 1929 and 1930
campaigns.
The Olympic team will have two
captains, this year; the new plan
will see Gardiner Mallonee directing the work of the defense while
Norman Robinson will lead the attack.
The Jays are anxious to continue
their series of victories over the
Olympic Club, having been victorious by the scores of 4-2, and 4-0 in
1929 and 1930. For a number of
the prospective players the coming
engagement will be their first varsity experience.

Of The Musical Club
Elliott, Kolb And Other Old Members Of The Club
Are Present.

merited on past activities of the organizations. Martin Elliot, pres.,
'30, and Donald Vannernan, manager, '23, joined in supply reminiscences of their membership.
Certificates Awarded

Following the addresses, Peake
presented certificates of membership to those who had been faithful
in service, including about 50 men.
Richard Van Atta was awarded the
first varsity seal of the new type

for 3 years' outstanding service. It
was announced that possibly 4 or 5
more men would receive seals in
June.
John L. Sullivan, '32, was announced to have been elected to
succeed Bert Clarke as leader of
the Blue Jay Orchestra. Wilson
Shugerman and Milton Smith, both
of '33, were elected by ballot to
succeed Levy and Sharretts as
junior managers. The competency
of the latter was cited as recommendation for their being elected.
Evening Is Success

The banquet which was held at
the Southern Hotel was attended
by over 60 persons of affiliation
with the club, Harry Kriel, Robert
George, and Donald Sharretts, former members, attending as guests.
The evening was featured by a
great deal of hilarity.
Peake called for the University
Ode by the Glee Club to open the
evening and it was closed by the
singing of the medley, "Dear Old
Johnny Hopkins," and "Frankie
and Johnnie."

to the fullest extent. Compromise
will lessen its strength. A new power ought be awarded the body. The
Student Council must serve as the
mediating body between students
conflicting with the faculty in any
manner, and students desiring the
repeal of an out-of-date disturbance. With such an additional power, ours will be a more beloved
Student Council.
This is a difficult article to write;
the faults of the campus are difficult
to understand. The undergraduate
must learn his place in the University scale, it must build the future
college from itself, it ought to cooperate more completely with its
best friend—its Dean.
Twenty years from now, the authors will be forgotten, this disorder unrecognizable, and the College of Arts and Sciences a recognized body. Out-of-town-students
will not enter under the delusion
that the college insures admission
to the Medical School—but because
of its educational fame. Radicalists will be properly- squelched. The
faculty will be a harmless, harmonious group of old-timers. Sports
and periodicals may or may not
vanish, but Homewood will be
Homewood—the undergrads will
still date Lutherville women rather
than those or Goucher—the Dorm
will still have its waterfights—the
food will still be condemned as horrible—courses will still be getting
tougher—and other classes will be
preparing for graduation. In the
meantime you and I will be striving to earn bread and butter.

Two Were Wounded

The wounding of the undergraduates—J. C. Bryson and
Robert G. Shirley among them—
occurred after a group of undergraduates had hurled snowballs
into windows of the Alumnia Memorial Hall, breaking a number of
panes. After a second missile had
entered the room of the graduate
student, he grasped a heavy air revolver and fired shot after shot at
the fleeing students.
Many of the slugs passed through
the clothing of the snowballthrowers.

Disturbed by the lassitude displayed by members of his 8.30
A. M. classes, Dr. Broadus Mitchell,
associate professor of Political
Economy, attributed this apathy to
sparsity of breakfasts eaten, after
an investigation last Friday morning. He amassed an imposing list
of statistics as to the repasts eaten
by yawning undergrads.
Dr. Mitchell's findings are regarded by many as being revolutionary,
in that they present a phase of the
college man's life that hitherto has
been disregarded, and which may
be the primary reason for the anipathy of all college students against
early morning classes.
